eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons

Class Task

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.Task

  • public class Task
extends java.lang.Object
    A task is a particular instance of an action execution, a job. It belongs to the executing object, was ordered by requesting object, it can be in certain states (only one state at a time) has a record of how long the execution takes and there is a return value associated with it. For more information about how OGWAPI handles the incoming requests for job execution please have look at action. After a task is created a UUID style task ID is automatically generated and serves as a reference for the ordering object to poll for the task's status. The valid states for each task are following: pending --> running --> finished \ | \ v \-> failed To easier grasp the relationship between actions and tasks, consider the following example: Imagine a door (object) that is capable of opening (action) and closing (action). When Bob steps up to the closed door he invokes an action (opening) and this particular execution (Bob's opening of the door) is referenced to as a task. This task has its own ID and can be polled for status at any time, to see whether or not it is already done. When Alice also wants to interact with door's actions, but her tasks need to line up behind Bob's, pending their executions until the former tasks are finished. One thing that needs to be realized in the mind of an integrator is, that the particular object only needs to be able to respond correctly to start and stop a task and must be able to call an update end point. The rest is done by the OGWAPI.
    Author:
    sulfo

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public NetworkMessageResponse start()
        Starts the execution of this task.
        Returns:
        Response from the AgentConnector or null if the task is not in a state that permits starting.

      • updateRunningTask

        public boolean updateRunningTask(java.lang.String taskStatus,
                                 java.lang.String returnValue)
        Method for updating a running task. Can change a status or a return value of the task. Only running task can be updated and it is only possible to either: remain in the running state switch to finished state switch to failed state
        Parameters:
        taskStatus - New status of the task - this method uses string value.
        returnValue - New return value. This will overwrite the old one if there is any.
        Returns:
        True if the task was updated successfully, false otherwise (this happens when invalid state was provided.

      • updateRunningTask

        public boolean updateRunningTask(byte taskStatus,
                                 java.lang.String returnValue)
        Method for updating a running task. Can change a status or a return value of the task. Only running task can be updated and it is only possible to either: remain in the running state switch to finished state switch to failed state
        Parameters:
        taskStatus - New status of the task - this method uses byte value.
        returnValue - New return value. This will overwrite the old one if there is any.
        Returns:
        True if the task was updated successfully, false otherwise (this happens when invalid state was provided.

      • cancel

        public NetworkMessageResponse cancel(java.lang.String body,
                                     java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parameters)
        Cancels a running or pending task.
        Parameters:
        body - Body to be sent to the object when canceling.
        parameters - Parameters to be sent along with the body.
        Returns:
        Response from the AgentConnector or null if the task is not in a state that permits canceling.

        public long getEndTime()
        Retrieves the Unix time of the moment when the task was moved into failed/finished state.
        Returns:

        Translates the status string to byte value.

        Returns:
